questions.text: A middle-aged woman presents to the clinic with significant astigmatism. The following finding is noted on closer examination. What is the ideal course of management?
questions.solution:
In a patient with a progressive pterygium causing astigmatism, excision of the pterygium along with conjunctival autograft is the preferred management.

Pterygium is a wing-shaped fold of the conjunctiva extending into the cornea. It is commonly seen in people who live in hot climates and in those who work outdoors.

Clinically the patient may present with symptoms such as: 

  • Cosmetic complaints
  • Foreign body sensation and irritation
  • Defective vision/astigmatism when the pterygium extends into the pupillary area
  • Diplopia

Medical management includes tear substitutes, topical corticosteroids, and sunglasses. Surgical management is preferred in patients with significant cosmetic defects, visual impairment, and other such complications.

Surgical excision with free conjunctival limbal autograft is the preferred technique for most pterygiums. In case of recurrent or large pterygium, surgical excision with amniotic membrane graft and mitomycin C is preferred.

questions.text: An 8-year old child presented with right-sided proptosis. Biopsy of the orbital mass was done and histopathological examination revealed this picture. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis is Rhabdomyosarcoma.

The older age of the child presenting with proptosis suggests Rhabdomyosarcoma (average age 7 to 8 years) than Retinoblastoma (average age at presentation is 18 months).

The histopathology shows elongated to round spindle cells with features of skeletal muscle in different stages of embryogenesis with a highly eosinophilic cytoplasm and hyperchromatic nuclei – the embryonal type of RMS

Rhabdomyosarcoma is classified into 4 major subtypes

    1. Embryonal: Makes up 80% of orbital rhabdomyosarcomas and presents most commonly in young children (mean age 7-8)
    2. Alveolar subtype exhibits small, round, densely appearing cells that are loosely arranged, with septae that are similar to the alveoli of the lung; carries the worst prognosis
    3. Botryoid - variant of embryonal rhabdomyosarcoma; subepithelial grape-like aggregates of tumor cells; seen most commonly in infants.
    4. Pleomorphic

Immunohistochemistry is useful in identifying skeletal muscle proteins, such as alpha-actin, myosin, desmin and myoglobin.

questions.text: A 24-year-old female patient came with complaints of floaters and blurring of vision in both eyes for a few weeks.  Fundoscopic examination shows inferior snow banking.  What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of a young female presenting with floaters, blurring of vision, and fundoscopy showing snow banking is suggestive of intermediate uveitis or pars planitis

Intermediate uveitis is the inflammation involving pars plana ciliaris, peripheral retina, choroid, and vitreous base. It is predominantly seen in young females and most often presents with floaters and bilateral blurring of vision.

Snow banking is the hallmark of intermediate uveitis. It refers to greyish white fibrovascular plaques over the pars plana, with or without peripheral retinal periphlebitis. This occurs due to the coalescence of snowball opacities.

Other Signs of intermediate uveitis:

  • Snow-ball opacities (Ant’s egg opacities)- typical exudates present near the ora Serrata in the inferior quadrant
  • Few keratic precipitates (KP) due to spillover anterior uveitis

Other options:

Option A: Anterior uveitis or iridocyclitis is the inflammation of tissue from the iris up to the pars plicata of the ciliary body. It is the most common form of uveitis. They present with:

  • Circumcorneal conjunctival hyperemia
  • Aqueous flare  
  • Keratin precipitates (KPs) 
  • Posterior synechiae  

Option C: Posterior uveitis is the inflammation of the choroid with or without inflammation of the retina. They are classified as:

  • Choroiditis  
  • Chorioretinitis  
  • Retinochoroditis  
  • Neuroretinitis  

Option D: Fuchs' uveitis or Fuchs heterochromatic iridocyclitis is a chronic non-granulomatous condition. They are usually unilateral. A difference in color between the iris of both eyes termed heterochromia iridis is characteristically seen here. Posterior synechiae are absent. A characteristic stellate-shaped keratic precipitates are located diffusely over the entire corneal epithelium.

questions.text: A 20-year-old man with a history of repeated pain over the medial canthus and chronic use of nasal decongestants presents to the outpatient department with high-grade fever and chills, headache, and bilateral proptosis. On eliciting further history, it is brought to light that the proptosis began in the right eye, and a few days later, the left eye was also affected. Which of the following is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• Pain over the medial canthus and use of nasal decongestants indicate that the patient was suffering from sinusitis, which can spread to cause any of the options, i.e., orbital cellulitis, cavernous sinus thrombosis, or panopthalmitis.
  • The differentiating feature here is the presentation pattern and bilaterality of the proptosis.
  • In cavernous sinus thrombosis, proptosis is initially unilateral but soon becomes bilateral due to the spread of infection to the contralateral sinus through the intercavernous communication. Also, cavernous sinus thrombosis presents with high-grade fever with chills, rigor, and headache.
  • On the other hand, orbital cellulitis and panophthalmitis are unilateral conditions.

Differential diagnosis of acute inflammatory proptosis

Clinical features Cavernous sinus thrombosis Orbital cellulitis Panophthalmitis
Laterality Initially unilateral but soon becomes bilateral Unilateral Unilateral
Vision Not affected in early stage affected Complete loss of vision 
Cornea and anterior chamber Clear Clear Hazy
Edema in the mastoid region Present (Pathognomonic of cavernous sinus thrombosis) Absent Absent
General symptoms with fever and prostration Marked Mild Mild

questions.text: Which of the following is defined as loss of eyelashes?
questions.solution:
Madarosis is the loss of eyelashes or eyebrows.

  • Loss of eyebrows is seen in leprosy and myxedema.
  • Loss of eyelashes is seen in chronic blepharitis.

 

Option A: Tylosis is a thickening of the tarsal border of the eyelid. 

Option C: Trichiasis is an inward misdirection of cilia, with the normal position of the lid margin.

Option D: Distichiasis is the presence of a double row of eyelashes.

questions.text: A 5-year-old female patient presented for her first complete eye examination after a school vision screening found unequal visual acuity. Her parents have not noted any eye problems. Visual acuity in the right eye was 20/20 and the left eye is 20/80. The rest of the examination including Fundus exam was unremarkable, What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most probable diagnosis from the given scenario is Amblyopia.

Amblyopia is an uncorrectable decrease in vision in one or both eyes with no apparent structural abnormality seen to explain it. It is a diagnosis of exclusion. Generally, a difference of two lines or more on an eye chart test of visual acuity between the two eyes or a best-corrected vision of 20/30 or worse would be defined as amblyopia. For example, our patient has 20/20 vision with the right eye and only 20/80 with the left and the left eye even after best-corrected vision couldn't achieve <20/30 vision, the left eye is said to be amblyopic.

Clinical features:

  • Decreased contrast sensitivity
  • Diminution of vision
  • Sunglass effect- brightness is less compared to the normal eye
  • Crowding phenomenon- slipping of images

Treatment of choice:

  • Occlusion of the normal eye (4 to 6 hours/day) using patches.
  • Penalization: Blurring of vision using atropine.

Prism correction is not the right treatment as the child doesn't have strabismus.

 

Other options:

Option A: Brain lesion does not cause difference in visual acuity in both eyes.

Option B: Retinoblastoma can be identified by fundoscopy.

Option C: Congenital cataract presents with loss of red reflex immediately after birth.

questions.text: A 60-year-old woman came with complaints of a gritty sensation in her eyes. On examination, Rose Bengal staining is positive. She is diagnosed with keratoconjunctivitis sicca. Which of the following layer of the tear film is deficient in this condition?
questions.solution:
Keratoconjunctivitis sicca is due to the deficiency of the aqueous layer of the tear film.

Causes of keratoconjunctivitis sicca:

  • Sjogren's syndrome (primary keratoconjunctivitis sicca)
  • Non-Sjogren's keratoconjunctivitis sicca
    • Primary age-related hyposecretion (most common)
    • Lacrimal gland deficiencies- congenital, infiltration by tumors or sarcoidosis, surgical removal
    • Lacrimal gland duct obstruction- old trachoma, burns,  SJS
    • Reflex hyposecretion (neurogenic causes)- Parkinson disease, 7th nerve palsy, reflex sensory block

Related Pearl: Layers of the Tear Film

Lipid layer

  • Outermost layer
  • Secreted by the meibomian, Zeis glands
  • Prevents evaporation of tears

Aqueous layer

  • Middle layer
  • Secreted by the lacrimal and accessory lacrimal glands
  • Provides lubrication

Mucin layer  

  • Innermost layer
  • Secreted by the goblet cells of the conjunctiva
  • Help in spreading the tear film over the ocular surface

The maximum density of the goblet cells is seen on the nasal bulbar conjunctiva.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents to the casualty with a sudden loss of vision and painful ocular movements. On examination of the affected eye, a relative afferent pupillary defect with a normal optic disc is seen. Visual field testing was done which revealed central scotoma in the same eye. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a sudden painful loss of vision in the absence of fundoscopic changes, RAPD and central scotoma is suggestive of optic neuritis, specifically retrobulbar neuritis. 

There are 3 types of optic neuritis: papillitis, neuroretinitis, and retrobulbar neuritis. The common causes of retrobulbar neuritis include demyelinating disorders such as multiple sclerosis (MS) and neuromyelitis optica (NMO or Devic's disease).

Clinically, optic neuritis is characterized by sudden, progressive visual loss.  Ocular movements are painful in retrobulbar neuritis and painless in papillitis and neuroretinitis. Glowing sensations known as phosphenes may be induced with sound or movement. Color vision may also be impaired. 

On examination, Marcus Gunn pupil or relative afferent pupillary defect (RAPD) is usually noted due to asymmetric involvement. The most common visual field defect is a central or centrocecal scotoma. 

Type Retrobulbar neuritis Papillitis Neuroretinitis
Pathology Inflammation of the optic nerve behind the disc Inflammation of the optic nerve head  Inflammation of the optic nerve head and the macula
Fundus appearance Optic disc appears normal

Hyperemia and oedema of the optic disc with or without peri-papillary flame-shaped hemorrhages

 Macular star (due to exudates that form around macula)
Prevalence Most common in adults

Most common in children

 Least common type
Associated conditions Strong association with demyelinating disorders like MS, NMO

Weak association with demyelinating disorders

 Cat-scratch disease, Lyme disease, Syphilis etc.

 

The image below shows papillitis.

 

The image below shows macular star appearance in neuroretinitis.

Causes of RAPD:

  • Severe retinal disease (e.g., central retinal artery occlusion, extensive retinal detachment)
  • Maculopathy (macular degeneration )
  • Optic nerve lesions (e.g., optic neuritis, retrobulbar neuritis in multiple sclerosis , anterior ischemic optic neuropathy , glaucoma)
  • Optic tract lesions (e.g., infarction)

Causes of central/centrocaecal scotoma

  • Optic neuritis
  • Compressive lesion eg. Pituitary adenoma
  • Optic neuropathy due to
  • Poor nutrition
  • Tobacco
  • Alcohol
  • Drug- induced optic neuropathy
  • Toxin- induced optic neuropathy
  • Hereditary optic atrophy
  • Sarcoidosis
  • Leukemia

questions.text: A 56-year-old diabetic is  having double vision with downward gaze .  She has no other complaints. What could be the reason for the symptoms?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario suggests trochlear nerve palsy.

In 4th nerve palsy, the superior oblique is affected, causing:

  • The weakness of depression in eye: Mainly seen when the eye is adducted (depression during abducted position is a function of Inferior rectus)
  • Weakness of abduction in eye
  • Failure of intorsion: Cause of diplopia

The main actions of the superior oblique are intorsion (incyclotorsion), and depression in adduction.

Hence, the patient will have difficulty in looking downwards when the eyes are in an adducted position. Diabetes, hypertension, and atherosclerosis affect the vasa nervosum of the cranial nerves leading to ischemia of the nerves. It results in paralysis.

Other options:

Option B: In 3rd nerve palsy (oculomotor nerve) - Due to the involvement of the superior rectus and medial rectus, elevation and adduction will also be impaired, which is not the case here.

Option D: In 6th nerve palsy (abducens nerve) - Due to the involvement of only the lateral rectus, abduction will be impaired and not depression.

Related Pearl: Origins of cranial nerves at the base of the brain

Cranial nerve origins as seen in gross anatomy:

  • III cranial nerve: Midbrain at the level of the superior colliculus.  
  • IV cranial nerve: Midbrain at the level of inferior colliculus - the only nerve the exits from the dorsal aspect
  • V cranial nerve: The substance of pons 
  • VI, VII, and VIII cranial nerves:  Pontomedullary junction
  • IX, X, and XI cranial nerves(nucleus ambiguus): Posterolateral sulcus   
  • XII cranial nerve: Anterolateral sulcus (between pyramid and olive)

questions.text: An industrial worker was admitted to the hospital after an eye injury sustained while cutting stone with a hammer and iron chisel. A foreign body was suspected to be impacted in his eye. Which of the following is the best investigation for foreign body localization?
questions.solution:
CT scan is the best method for intraocular foreign body (IOFB) localization.

The foreign bodies most likely to penetrate and be retained in the eye are minute chips of iron or steel. While chipping stone with an iron chisel, the chip of the iron chisel is more likely to enter the eye than the stone. A foreign body entering the eye may cause damage by:

  • mechanical effects
  • introduction of infection
  • reacting with the intraocular tissues

Anteroposterior and lateral view X-rays are recommended for locating an IOFB as most foreign bodies are radio-opaque. Ultrasonographic localization can tell the position of even non-radiopaque foreign bodies. CT scan is the best method of IOFB localization.

MRI is contraindicated for metallic IOFB.MRI can be detrimental for a patient with a history of an intraocular foreign body (IOFB) after cutting stone with a hammer and chisel. It can cause further damage by producing movements of the foreign body if it is magnetic. The use of MRI is contraindicated for metallic (iron) foreign bodies and is not recommended as a screening procedure.

Management: A foreign body should always be removed unless:

  • it is inert and probably sterile
  • little damage has been done to vision 
  • the process of removal will destroy sight

 

Siderosis bulbi refers to the ocular degenerative changes produced by an iron foreign body. It usually occurs 2 months to 2 years after the injury. This condition is due to the electrolytic dissociation of the metal by an intrinsic resting current in the eye which disseminates the metal, combining it with cellular proteins and cause atrophy.

Clinical features:

  • Iris: first stained greenish and later turns reddish-brown, causing heterochromia iridis.
  • Pupil: iron deposition in sphincter leads to mydriasis.
  • Lens: iron deposition in a radial fashion on the anterior capsule of the lens, leading to anterior capsular cataract.
  • Retina: pigmentary retinopathy; followed by atrophy of the retina and retinal pigmentary epithelium.
  • Secondary open-angle Glaucoma: due to damage to the trabecular meshwork.

questions.text: A 21-year-old man presented with the following lesion in his eye. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The image depicts Bitot's spot, a pathognomonic feature of xerophthalmia. Hence, the likely diagnosis in this patient presenting with the above lesion is xerophthalmia.

Bitot's spot is a triangular, silvery-white, foamy patch on the bulbar conjunctiva which is usually bilateral. The most common site is temporal.

Ocular manifestations of vitamin A deficiency include loss of sensitivity to green light (earliest to appear), nyctalopia (night blindness), and xerophthalmia.

Xerophthalmia includes conjunctival xerosis (dryness) with Bitot’s spots (white patches of keratinized epithelium appearing on the sclera), corneal ulcers, and keratomalacia (softening of the cornea) that leads to corneal scarring and ultimately, blindness.

Related Pearl: WHO grading of Vitamin A deficiency

The term xerophthalmia is reserved to cover all the ocular manifestations of vitamin A deficiency.

Stage Features Pathophysiology
XN Night blindness Lack of rhodopsin
X1A Conjunctival Xerosis Conjunctival epithelial alteration, loss of goblet cells
X1B Bitot’s spots Conjunctival keratinization and plaque formation
X2 Corneal xerosis Corneal epithelial alteration
X3A Corneal ulceration/ Keratomalacia affecting <1/3rd of the corneal surface Liquefaction of corneal stroma
X3B Corneal ulceration/ Keratomalacia affecting >1/3rd of the corneal surface              -
XS Corneal scar              -
XF Xerophthalmic fundus Degeneration of the retinal pigment epithelium

The first symptom of xerophthalmia is nyctalopia.

The first sign of xerophthalmia is conjunctival xerosis.

The pathognomonic feature of xerophthalmia is the appearance of Bitot's spots.

Note:

Up to the level of Stage 2, the manifestations are reversible if treated with vitamin A supplements.

However, active conjunctival xerosis and Bitot’s spots begin to resolve within 2—5 days after supplementation. Most will disappear within 2 weeks, although a significant proportion of temporal lesions may persist in shrunken form and may therefore not be completely reversible.

questions.text: Which is the most common epithelial lacrimal gland tumor?
questions.solution:
Pleomorphic adenoma is the most common epithelial lacrimal gland tumor.

The most common epithelial tumors, in order of frequency, are as follows:

  • Benign mixed tumor (BMT), also known as pleomorphic adenoma (PA)
  • Adenoid cystic carcinoma (ACC)
  • Pleomorphic adenocarcinoma (ACA)
  • Mucoepidermoid carcinoma

 Most Commons:

Most common tumor of lacrimal gland: Pleomorphic adenoma

Most common epithelial tumor of lacrimal gland: Pleomorphic adenoma

Most common malignant epithelial tumor of lacrimal gland: Adenoid cystic carcinoma

It is used for the measurement of the angle of the posterior chamber.

questions.text: The  visual field defect usually found in craniopharyngioma is?
questions.solution:
The visual field defect usually found in craniopharyngioma is bitemporal hemianopia.

Craniopharyngiomas are benign masses usually presenting in the suprasellar region arising near the pituitary stalk and can produce functional impairment of the hypophysis due to mass effect. The clinical features of craniopharyngiomas include headaches,visual field defects,growth failure and delayed sexual maturation due to pituitary hypofunction. CT scan may show calcifications in the supra-sellar region. Treatment includes trans-sphenoidal resection of the tumour followed by adjuvant chemotherapy.

Lesions of the optic chiasma can cause bitemporal hemianopia.i.e, loss of vision in the temporal halves of both visual fields. Nasal fibers of each retina cross through the chiasma at this level and hence, these fibers are compromised.

Other causes of chiasmal lesions are

  • Pituitary adenoma (most common)
  • Aneurysm of the anterior communicating artery
  • Meningioma
  • Glioma

Other options:

Option B) Binasal hemianopia is a rare visual field defect also caused due to lesions at the optic chiasma.  

Option C) Superior quadrantopia is also known as pie in the sky defect and is caused when lesions affect the inferior fibres of the optic radiations in the temporal lobe.  

Option D)Inferior quadrantopia is also known as pie on the floor defect and is caused due to lesions affecting the superior fibres of the optic radiations in the parietal lobe.

questions.text: A patient's eye was hit by a tennis ball and developed Hyphema. What is the likely source of bleeding ?
questions.solution:
Circulus arteriosus major is responsible for Hyphaema (blood in the anterior chamber).

Hyphaema:

Causes of Hyphaema:

  • Ocular injuries
  • Postoperative
  • Herpes zoster iritis
  • Gonococcal iritis
  • Intraocular tumor
  • Spontaneous (from rubeosis iridis)

Two-way irrigation and aspiration cannula can be used for aspirating hyphaema.

Blood Supply of Eye:

Cornea: Avascular

Uvea: 3 arteries are important.

  • Short post ciliary artery- Choroid
  • Long post ciliary artery-2 in number join each other near ciliary muscle with anterior ciliary arteries to form circulus arteriolar major (C A major).
  • Short anterior ciliary arteries join long posterior ciliary arteries to form C A major.
  • Branches from circulus arteriolar major go to the pupillary border to form circulus arteriosus minor(C A minor).

Retina:

  • Outer four layers-choriocapillaries (RPE, rods and cones, ELM, outer nuclear layer)
  • Inner layers- Central retinal artery
  • Macula- Branches of central retinal artery + Choriocapillaries.
  • Foveola- Avascular

Optic Nerve Head:

  • Surface nerve fibre layer- From retinal arteriole.
  • Lamina cribrosa- From ciliary vessels derived from posterior ciliary artery and arterial circle of Zinn and Haller.

questions.text: A patient presents with a sudden painless loss of vision in his right eye. On fundus examination, the following finding was seen. Which among the following conditions is likely?
questions.solution:
The image shows a splashed tomato appearance which is characteristic of central retinal vein occlusion (CRVO). 

CRVO refers to sudden or acute occlusion of the central retinal vein. It presents with a sudden loss of vision. On examination, RAPD (relative afferent pupillary defect) is present.

Funduscopy shows engorged and tortuous retinal veins, massive retinal hemorrhages with splashed tomato appearance, and cotton wool spots. The disc is edematous and hyperemic. Changes that occur later include neovascularization at the disc or periphery with pigmentary changes at the macula.

Complications:

  • Rubeosis iridis or neovascularization of the iris
  • Neovascular glaucoma (NVG) or 100 day glaucoma
  • Vitreous hemorrhage

100-day glaucoma is a type of neovascular glaucoma (NVG) and is so-called because it typically develops 3 months after the episode of CRVO.

Other options:

Option A- The funduscopy findings in central retinal artery occlusion include pale retina, thread-like arteries, a cherry-red spot in the macula, and cattle trucking (segmentation of blood in the retinal veins). It is shown below.

Option C: The funduscopy in retinal detachment shows detachment of fovea and macula, as shown below.

Option D: Fundoscopy changes in retinitis pigmentosa include perivascular retinal hyperpigmentation, narrow retinal arterioles, atrophy of retinal pigment epithelium, and disc pallor. It is shown below.

questions.text: A 61-year-old university professor presents with a loss of vision in his left eye. He describes the sensation as a curtain being drawn over his affected eye. In addition, 7 days ago the patient noticed what he described as flashing lights and floaters. He gives a history of having cataract surgery in the same eye 3 weeks ago. A B-scan image of his left eye is shown below. What could be his condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the B-scan suggest a diagnosis of rhegmatogenous retinal detachment. It is due to the accumulation of fluid between neurosensory retina(NSR) and retinal pigment epithelium (RPE) due to a retinal tear.

Definition of retinal detachment: The separation of the neurosensory retina from the RPE.

Types of Retinal detachment:

A. Rhegmatogenous retinal detachment- fluid accumulates after a break (tear) occurs in the retina.

  • Causes:
    • High myopes
    • Retinoschisis-splitting of neurosensory retina plus vitreous degeneration
      • Typical retinoschisis-split at the level of the outer plexiform layer
      • Atypical retinoschisis-split at the level of the nerve fiber layer
    • Trauma
    • Pseudophakia
    • Aphakia
  • The most dangerous type of retinal break is horseshoe tear.
  • The most dangerous location of retinal break is the supero-temporal retina. 
  • Clinical features
    • Photopsia-flashes of light due to vitreoretinal traction at the site of the break
    • Floaters
    • Visual field defect- a black curtain/veil in front of the eye
  • Signs
    • Hypotony- as the liquefied vitreous in the subretinal space is absorbed through the RPE.
    • Shafers sign-pigments in the anterior vitreous (tobacco dusting) are a feature of fresh retinal detachment.
    • The detached retina is convex in configuration. The surface is corrugated with undulations.
  • Treatment
    • Prophylactic laser barrage
    • Scleral buckling
    • Pneumatic retinopexy
    • Pars plana vitrectomy 

B. Tractional retinal detachment: Fibro-vascular membranes in the vitreous due to long-standing retinal neovascularization exert traction on the retina. 

  • Causes
    • Proliferative diabetic retinopathy
    • Central retinal venous occlusion
    • Eales disease
    • Retinopathy of Prematurity(ROP)
  • Signs
    • The detached retina is concave in configuration. No breaks are seen
  • Treatment
    • Pars plana vitrectomy with endo photocoagulation. 

C. Exudative retinal detachment: Exudative fluid from the choroid, collects in the subretinal space leading to retinal detachment.

  • Causes
    • Inflammatory conditions like choroiditis, posterior scleritis
    • Choroidal tumours like melanoma
    • Toxaemia of pregnancy
    • Malignant hypertension
    • Coats disease
  • Clinical features
    • Floaters due to vitritis but no photopsia
    • Visual field defect
  • Signs
    • The detached retina is convex in configuration. The surface is smooth. No break is seen.
    • Shifting fluid is seen.
  • Treatment
    • Systemic steroids
    • Treatment of the cause

questions.text: Identify the below finding:
questions.solution:
Ptosis:

It is abnormal drooping of upper eyelid.Ptosis is drooping of the upper lid to a level that that covers more than 2mm of the superior cornea.Ptosis is generally unilateral,in over 70% of individuals.

Types:

  1. Congenital ptosis
  2. Acquired ptosis
    • Neurogenic ptosis: It is caused by innervational defects such as third nerve palsy, Horner’s syndrome.
    • Myogenic ptosis: It occurs due to acquired disorders of the LPS muscle or of the myoneural Junction. - Myasthenia gravis
    • Aponeurotic ptosis: It develops due to defects of the levator aponeurosis.
    • Mechanical ptosis: It may result due to excessive weight on the upper lid as seen in patients with lid tumors, multiple chalazia and lid edema.

questions.text: A 7-year-old boy presented with a white pupillary reflex for which enucleation was done. The histopathological examination of the specimen revealed Flexner-Wintersteiner rosettes. What could be the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This child with a whitish pupillary reflex and Flexner-Winterstein rosettes on histopathological examination has retinoblastoma. Flexner Winterstein rosettes refer to an arrangement of columnar cells around a central lumen, which is highly characteristic of retinoblastoma.

Retinoblastoma is a malignant proliferation of immature retinal neural cells and is the most common intraocular malignancy in children. It is associated with mutations in the RB1 gene at chromosome 13q14. It belongs to small round blue cell tumours because the immature retinal neural cells are seen as small round cells with large nuclei.

White pupillary reflex or leukocoria is the most common presenting feature, followed by a squint which is usually convergent. Rarely, the child may present with nystagmus and defective vision. Image below showing leukocoria of left eye

Histopathology of the tumor shows small round cells with large nuclei. Microscopic features of a well-differentiated tumour include Flexner-Wintersteiner rosettes (highly specific of retinoblastoma), Homer-Wright rosettes, pseudorosettes, and fleurettes formation. Areas of necrosis and calcification can also be seen.

The histopathological image of retinoblastoma is shown below.

Treatment typically involves chemotherapy plus focal therapy. The commonly used three-drug regimen is the CVE regimen consisting of Vincristine, Carboplatin, and Etoposide. Focal therapy includes cryotherapy, laser photocoagulation, thermotherapy, plaque radiotherapy, and external beam radiotherapy.
Enucleation is done when
  • The tumor involves more than half of the retina
  • The optic nerve is involved
  • Glaucoma is present and the anterior chamber is involved

Other options:

Option B - Medulloblastoma is a malignant embryonal tumor of childhood that occurs exclusively in the cerebellum. Patients usually present with headaches, ataxia, and signs of brainstem involvement.

Histologically, the tumor is very densely cellular. Individual tumor cells have scant cytoplasm and elongated or crescent-shaped hyperchromatic nuclei. Tumor cells form Homer Wright rosettes. They express neuronal markers such as synaptophysin.

Option C - Rhabdomyosarcoma is the most common soft tissue sarcoma of childhood. The child usually presents with rapidly progressive unilateral proptosis. There are 4 subtypes - embryonal, alveolar, botyroid, and pleomorphic. Cells show light microscopic features of striated muscle differentiation. Immunohistochemistry is positive for desmin.

Option D - Astrocytoma of the retina and optic nerve head is rare. It is usually asymptomatic and is most frequently seen in tuberous sclerosis. Fundus examination reveals a yellowish or white plaque, nodule, or mulberry-like lesion. These lesions are semitransparent peripherally and calcified centrally.

Image showing calcified astrocytoma:

Related Pearl: Histological Features of CNS Tumors

Pilocytic Astrocytomas:

  • Biphasic architecture - loose microcystic component and dense fibrillary areas
  • Bipolar cells (tumor cells): thin, long hairlike processes that are GFAP - positive. 
  • Rosenthal fibers: eosinophilic corkscrew - shaped inclusions
  • Eosinophilic granular bodies: mulberry - like inclusions 

 

Medulloblastoma:

  • Very densely cellular, with sheets of small primitive appearing small blue cells
  • Individual tumor cells have scant cytoplasm and hyperchromatic nuclei that are frequently elongated or crescent-shaped
  • Tumor cells form Homer - Wright rosettes (pseudorosettes) with a central neuropil

 

Ependymoma:

  • Ependymal rosettes: gland - like round or elongated structures that resemble the embryologic ependymal canal, with long, delicate processes extending into the lumen 
  • Perivascular pseudorosettes: perivascular nuclear - free zone consisting of thin ependymal processes radiating toward the central blood vessel

 

Oligodendroglioma:

  • Fried - egg appearance: sheets of regular cells with spherical nuclei containing finely granular chromatin (similar to normal oligodendrocytes) surrounded by a clear halo of vacuolated cytoplasm. 
  • Chicken - wire capillaries: a delicate network of anastomosing capillaries

 

Retinoblastoma: 

  • Composed of collections of small, round cells with hyperchromatic nuclei
  • Flexner - Wintersteiner rosettes: arrangements of a single layer of tumor cells around an apparent lumen
  • Homer - Wright rosettes: a ring of cells with an eosinophilic fibrillary center
  • Fleurettes: retinoblastoma cells that have undergone greater photoreceptor differentiation and group together as a bouquet. Fleurettes lack mitosis or necrosis.

questions.text: A patient presented to OPD with complaints of fever left eye lid swelling for the past two days as shown below . He had a mild flu-like illness a week ago but no history of trauma. There is no chemosis or any protrusion of the eyeball. Visual acuity, IOP, ocular motility, and pupils all were normal. Slit-lamp examination was unremarkable. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette with eyelid swelling and fever following an infection without proptosis, loss of visual acuity, and ophthalmoplegia are suggestive of preseptal cellulitis/ Periorbital cellulitis.

Preseptal cellulitis is an infection of the subcutaneous tissues anterior to the orbital septum.
 
Etiological agents: Staph. aureus, Strep. pyogens
 
Mode of spread: Skin trauma, insect bites, acute hordeolum, dacryocystitis, conjunctivitis, sinusitis, Upper respiratory tract infection, and middle ear infection.
 
Presentation:
  1. Tender, firm, erythematous eye lid swelling
  2. Conjunctiva - usually no chemosis
  3. Proptosis - absent
  4. Ocular movements - normal
  5. Visual acuity - normal
  6. Systemic symptoms: fever, leucocytosis

Treatment: Antibiotics with systemic analgesics and warm compresses.

Complications: May spread and develop into orbital cellulitis, abscess formation, meningitis, and cavernous sinus thrombosis.

Option A:  Panophthalmitis would have an intense purulent inflammation of the whole eyeball that could be seen on a slit-lamp.

Option B: Orbital cellulitis refers to the acute infection of the contents of the orbit behind the orbital septum.It  presents with pain, lid edema, erythema, chemosis, and axial proptosis.Increased pain with movement of eyes and ophthalmoplegia (decreased ocular motility) is a classic symptoms. There is a rapid loss of vision is due to the involvement of the optic nerve.

Option D: Endophthalmitis is defined as the inflammation of the inner structures of the eyeball, i.e., uveal tissue and retina, associated with the pouring of exudates into the vitreous cavity, anterior chamber, and posterior chamber.

questions.text: Which of the following nerve injury causes neurotrophic keratopathy?
questions.solution:
Neurotrophic keratopathy is due to loss of trigeminal nerve innervation resulting in partial or complete loss of sensation.

Causes:

  • Trigeminal ganglion surgical ablation for neuralgia
  • Stroke
  • Tumour
  • Peripheral neuropathy
  • Herpes simplex and herpes zoster keratitis (sectoral sensation loss)

Stages:

Stage 1: intrapalpebral epithelial irregularity, oedema and tiny focal deficits

Stage 2: Large persistent epithelial defects with rolled and thickened edges, assuming a punched out configuration

Stage 3: Stromal melting

Treatment: Topical lubricants, protection of the ocular surface with tarsorrhaphy, therapeutic silicone contact lenses, amniotic membrane patching.

 

Exposure keratopathy is caused by paralysis of the facial nerve.  

Exposure keratopathy

  • It is the result of incomplete lid closure (lagophthalmos), with the drying of the cornea despite normal tear production.
  • Causes 
    • Neuroparalytic, e.g., facial nerve palsy
    • Reduced muscle tone as in parkinsonism
    • Mechanical such as lid scarring
    • Proptosis

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false regarding accommodative esotropia?

choices.text: It is the most common type of squint.
Miotics are used as the treatment strategy in the high AC/A ratio
It is associated with high myopia.
Refractive type can be fully corrected by use of spectacles.

questions.solution:
Accommodative esotropia is associated with a high degree of hypermetropia (+4 to +7 D).

Accommodative esotropia is the most common type of squint. Typically presents around 2 to 3 years of age.

Types:

  1. Refractive
    • Associated with high hypermetropia
    • Fully correctable by spectacles
  2. Non-refractive type
    • Abnormal accommodative convergence/accommodation (AC/A) ratio
    • Fully corrected by bifocal glasses
    • Miotics useful in cases where glasses are unsuitable
      • Echothiophate causes iris cyst
      • Prevention of iris cysts- Phenylephrine drops
  3. Mixed type

The accommodative convergence/accommodation (AC/A) ratio is defined as the amount of convergence measured in prism diopters per unit (diopter) change in accommodation.

questions.text:
Match the following ocular examination findings with their pathology.
  1. Wessely's immune ring
  2. Vossius ring 
  3. Arcus lipoides
  4. Kayser-Fleischer ring
questions.solution:
The correct match is as follows:

Image A: Vossius ring
Image B: Arcus lipoides
Image C: Kayser-Fleischer ring
Image D: Wessely's immune ring

Vossius ring is a circular ring of faint or stippled opacity, seen on the anterior surface of the lens due to brown amorphous granules of pigment lying on the capsule of the lens. It is usually seen after blunt trauma to the eye and orbit.

It usually has about the same diameter as the contracted pupil. The force of the blow drives the cornea and iris backward and thus producing an impression of the iris on the lens as shown below. The resorption of the pigment results in discrete subcapsular opacities.

Arcus senilis (AS) or arcus lipoides/Gerontoxon.is usually an age-related lipid degeneration of the peripheral corneal that forms a light grey or bluish ring. AS is caused by leakage of lipoproteins (phospholipids and cholesterol) from limbal capillaries into the corneal stroma. Characteristically it is separated from the margin by a narrow zone of comparatively clear cornea.

It is the most common peripheral corneal opacity and is usually found in the elderly where it is considered a benign condition. When AS is found in patients less than 40 years old it is termed arcus juvenilis. It represents an increased risk for cardiovascular disease and warrants screening for an underlying lipid disorder.

Arcus senilis is shown in the image below.

Intraocular deposition of copper is seen in Wilson's disease and would result in a KF ring/ Kayser-Fleischer ring on the cornea. A brownish-yellow zone is seen in the peripheral Descemet membrane of the cornea. Anterior capsular cataract, also knowns as a sunflower cataract may be seen in some patients.

The immune ring of Wessely is formed by infiltrates of stroma in a circular fashion in fungal corneal ulcers. It is due to a type 3 hypersensitivity reaction (antigen-antibody complex).

The immune ring of Wessely can be made out as a deep stromal haze in a slit lamp. It occurs as a result of the deposition of antigen-antibody complexes in the stroma. Once deposited it draws the immune cells, inciting further inflammation.

The given shows an ulcer in the cornea and the adjacent immune ring of Wessely.
